description:

description:
## Goal
Optimize carousel assets on the [/education](https://about.gitlab.com/solutions/education/) page. We're currently loading over 20mb of images, causing the transitions to be slow.

title: Brand marketing landing page refresh
description:
## Goal
We would like to refresh (not redesign) our brand marketing landing page with some small adjustments ([figma comp from brand design team for direction](https://www.figma.com/file/cpxpcnUjCEDH87otFP42zZ/Brand-strategy-landing-page?node-id=313%3A1599&t=vxdM0abipJEBkjqJ-1)) to better align with campaign messaging and improve engagement with our content.

Adjustments: 
- Hero: Swap out the Hero image with new creative
- Hero: Update the Watch Video CTA and link (Pending final link to "What Is GitLab?" new video).
- Hero: remove the "free trial" link to focus user engagement on the Watch video CTA and scroll down the page.
- Customer Stories: Move this module up above the logo strip to encourage discovery and engagement.
- Customer Stories: Change the module layout to present all three customer stories on the page. 

**Context for surfacing customer stories**: 
Based on 3 months of historical brand landing page data (q4FY23 - Q1FY24) our top 5 page clicks are:

1. Header / Free Trial
2. Hero / Watch Video CTA
3. Hero / Free Trial
4. Header / Site Search
5. In-line / GitLab Homepage

**Awareness level content:**

11. Read the Blog (Cadence is Everything)
12. Hackerone customer story

With the suggested minimal edits above, we believe that awareness level content will get an increased number of clicks. We will monitor this iteration and measure the results. 

#### Jobs To Be Done
* **Situation**: *Live April 5th, 2023 (possibly sooner, if edit proves minimal)*
* **Motivation**: *We will be featuring our new What is GitLab video and driving traffic to customer stories through a brand ad campaign as soon as this is refreshed.*
* **Outcome**: * Feature our new What is GitLab video and surface awareness level content (customer stories) closer to the fold*

#### Please provide more information related to this request
Make sure the information you provide is relevant for your request. If unsure, please provide all the fields. Add/remove rows as needed.

**If this is urgent, what is the business need for the urgency?**
- [x]  Yes: `See note with Situation.  We'd love to get this in market sooner if possible. Look to your team for guidance.`
- [ ]  No

If the requestor is not the DRI, find out if the DRI is aware of the request / wants to change things.

**Does anyone in leadership have eyes on this project?**
- [x]  Yes @dsteer 
- [ ]  No

**Compliance / legal / accessibility regulations to be aware of?**
- [ ] Yes: `Please describe why`
- [x] No: `video has been approved and all other changes exist within the live and approved brand landing page`

**What is the ultimate end goal vision vs the MVC1 iteration?**
 - `To add the What is GitLab? video to the brand landing page, to have our hero image mirror current digital campaign look and feel and to move customer stories closer to the fold/ top of the scroll to increase consumer engagement with awareness level content.`

**How do we measure success?**
 - `Once live we will continue to monitor engagement of the content through our brand landing page dashboard "clicks by page section."

**What analytics / data will we need to set-up?**
- [x] Yes: we'd want to update the What is GitLab video (Vimeo).  But all other page analytics should be up to date.
- [] 

## Page(s)
Which page(s) are involved in this request?
* `[Software.Faster | GitLab](https://about.gitlab.com/software-faster/)`

## DCI
[DRI, Consulted, Informed](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/people-group/directly-responsible-individuals/#dri-consulted-informed-dci)

- [x] DRI: @jmatthewj 
- [x] Consulted: @amittner @rclayman 
- [ ] Informed: `Everyone`

## In scope
What is within scope of this request?

- [x] Deliverable 1
**Edits** 
- Hero: Swap out the Hero image with new creative
- Hero: Update the Watch Video CTA and link (Pending final link to "What Is GitLab?" new video.
- Hero: remove the "free trial" link to focus user engagement on the Watch video CTA and scroll down the page.
- Customer Stories: Move this module up above the logo strip to encourage discovery and engagement.
- Customer Stories: Change the module layout to present all three customer stories on the page.

**Design / Layout**: Brand design to provide comp for [this figma design](https://www.figma.com/file/cpxpcnUjCEDH87otFP42zZ/Brand-strategy-landing-page?node-id=313%3A1599&t=vxdM0abipJEBkjqJ-1)

**Video / What Is GitLab?**: pending final edits.  Should have an update on this link EOW (3/23/23)

## Requirements

title: MVC 5 Navigation - Add links to Why Ultimate and Why Premium to the navigation
description:
## Goal
We would like to build MVC 5 of the navigation. This iteration adds:  
1. links to Why Ultimate and Why Premium to the navigation which will improve traffic to these pages as measured by pageviews.
2. redesigns the solutions drop down
3. adds new icons 

#### Jobs To Be Done
* **Situation**: *When a prospective customer is deciding between GitLab Ultimate or GitLab Premium*
* **Motivation**: *We want to provide easy access to relevant information*
* **Outcome**: *So we can help the prospective customer make the best decision for their needs.*

#### Please provide more information related to this request
Make sure the information you provide is relevant for your request. If unsure, please provide all the fields. Add/remove rows as needed.

**Does anyone in leadership have eyes on this project?**
- [x]  Yes `@akramer @dsteer` 
- [ ]  No

**Compliance / legal / accessibility regulations to be aware of?**
- [ ] Yes: `Please describe why`
- [x] No: `Please describe why`

**How do we measure success?**
 - Notes from @dennischarukulvanich: The Why Ultimate page is ranked #43 in visibility with 3,880 pageviews in February compared to other about.gitlab.com pages. The page has high engagement with a 61% click rate. It has the 3rd highest SaaS trial conversion rate at 4.4% behind /free-trial and /pricing/feature-comparison. Roughly 10% of purchases viewed the page.

title: [Eng] Run A/B test V2 for sales and trial header CTAs
description:
## Goal We would like to run a A/B test on the free trial CTA in the nav. Variant 1: Default black button Variant 2: Glean black button ## In scope What is within scope of this request? - [ ] Create the black glean button in the navigation repository - [ ] Create a A/B test in Launch Darkly for testing the black glean variant - [ ] Running a successful A/B test for the nav buttons - verifying that data is collected in Launch Darkly & GTM - [ ] Determining what was wrong when we first implemented the multivariant test - [ ] Updating our [handbook](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/digital-experience/engineering-ab-tests/) with clear documentation ## Requirements What are the requirements for this request? Checklist below is an example of common requirements, please check all that apply and adjust as necessary: - [ ] Copy writing - [ ] Illustration - [ ] Custom Graphics - [ ] Research - [ ] Data / Analytics - [ ] UX Design - [x] Engineering ### Target and Split - 50/50 (primary vs steel) ### Key Performance Indicators - Trial CTA click **Metrics to monitor:** - Trial CTA click - SaaS trial signup rate ### Estimated Experiment Duration Duration Calculator: https://www.abtasty.com/sample-size-calculator/
Roughly 2-3 days ## Engineering Notes ### LaunchDarkly Please set the conversion metric to measure:
- Control: Free Trial CTA click in the header - Variant: Free Trial CTA click in the header ### Google Analytics Push the following dataLayer code before DOM ready: ``` window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []; dataLayer.push({ 'event': 'launchDarklyExperiment', 'launchDarklyExperimentName': 'name of experiment', 'launchDarklyExperimentId': '0 or 1' }); ``` _Where:_
- name of experiment is the dynamic name of the LaunchDarkly experiment - 0 or 1 0 = control, 1 = variant Ensure the variant `` element has the following attributes: `data-nav="free trial"`

epic.title: Multivariate Test Design: Sales and Trial Header CTA

<script type="application/ld+json">

  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Article",
  "mainEntityOfPage": {
    "@type": "WebPage",
    "@id": "https://about.gitlab.com/topics/devsecops/"
  },
  "headline": "What is DevSecOps?",
  "description": "Effectively turn your DevOps methodology into a DevSecOps methodology",
  "image": "https://about.gitlab.com/_nuxt/image/da4ee5.png",

  "timeRequired":"PT05M",

    "@type": "Organization",

    "url": "https://about.gitlab.com/"
  },

title: [ENG] Localized French and Japanese Sales Landing page
description:
## Goal
We would like to create a localized French and Japanese sales landing page to the Buyer Experience repository. This will enable use to explore the full lifecycle of localizing a page to multiple langauges. 

- https://about.gitlab.com/fr-fr/sales 
- https://about.gitlab.com/ja-jp/sales 

#### Jobs To Be Done
* **Situation**: *When a user visits `/fr-fr/sales` or `/ja-jp/sales`  the see a french/japanese version of our sales page*
* **Motivation**: *We want to learn what the level of effort is to host localized versions of our BE pages in 3 languages*
* **Outcome**: *So we can make informed decisions about our technical localization strategy *

#### Please provide more information related to this request
Make sure the information you provide is relevant for your request. If unsure, please provide all the fields. Add/remove rows as needed.

**Does anyone in leadership have eyes on this project?**
- [ ]  Yes @djsulliv 
- [ ]  No

**What is the ultimate end goal vision vs the MVC1 iteration?**
 - Work with MarketingOps to identify french and Japanese versions of our sales form
 - Create a french version of our sales page in Buyer Experience
 - Create a Japanese version of our sales page in Buyer Experience
 - Have this page ignored by our Swiftype search tool
 - Have this page ignored by all search engines (IE Google)


**What analytics / data will we need to set-up?**
- [ ] Yes: We'll sync with @dennischarukulvanich on this once review app is up
- [ ] No

## Page(s)
Which page(s) are involved in this request?
* https://about.gitlab.com/fr-fr/sales 
* https://about.gitlab.com/ja-jp/sales 

## DCI
[DRI, Consulted, Informed](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/people-group/directly-responsible-individuals/#dri-consulted-informed-dci)

- [ ] DRI: @jariasc-ext 
- [ ] Consulted: @laurenbarker 
- [ ] Informed: `Everyone`

## In scope
What is within scope of this request?

- [ ] New Japanese sales page 
- [ ] Contact sales goes to Japanese form
- [ ] New french sales page 
- [ ] Contact sales goes to french form

## Requirements
What are the requirements for this request? Checklist below is an example of common requirements, please check all that apply and adjust as necessary:

- [ ] Copy writing
- [ ] Illustration
- [ ] Custom Graphics
- [ ] Research
- [ ] Data / Analytics
- [ ] UX Design
- [x] Engineering

title: [ENG] Personalizing Navigation with Demandbase
description:
## Goal

To utilize the [Demandbase API](https://support.demandbase.com/hc/en-us/sections/360011444531-API-Documentation) serve a personalized navigation if the visitor is coming from an Enterprise or SMB organization.

If the user is identified as Enterprise, we'll display a MVC to the navigation that results in increased engagement and conversions.

The goal of the issue is for the UX team to research the best strategy for personalizing the navigation if visitors are identified as an Enterprise or SMB visitor. From that research, then design a MVC personalized nav for enterprise visitors

title: [ENG]: Refactor ROI calculators
description:
To get the Time ROI calculator up and running quickly, I made a completely separate component from the Cost ROI calculator. If one calculator needs some CSS changed, you'd have to go into the other calculator's file and make that match as well.

I'd like to set aside some time to refactor the component to improve future developer experience, reusability, and ultimately minimize file page size.

Setting this as 4 points to focus on other critical issues in this iteration, but I'm happy to up those points if I end up getting a bigger window of time!

title: [ENG] Personalizing Navigation with GDK Cookie - MVC 1, verify it's there
description:
## Goal

We would like to use the first party cookie create as part of [this issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/digital-experience/buyer-experience/-/issues/1919) and _verify_ that it enable the marketing site to recognize a logged in Gitlab user by using dataLayer in the console.

No UI changes here - we just wan't to see an object in the datalayer that tells us the cookie is present. If we can prove it's there, we'll circle back with UX on next steps.

title: Investigate reoccurring artifact upload failures
description:
## Goal
In the last sprint, we have seen three separate incidents where the pipeline in www is failing because of the buyer-experience job. We have mitigated these incidents, but need to investigate a root cause. 


#### Details and Timeline

Thurs, Feb 2nd - [Incident-8354](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/digital-experience/buyer-experience/-/issues/1870): Pipelines for the buyer-experience job started 503-ing, implying "no access" to the artifact. After declaring a [prod incident](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/8354), it was discovered that the buyer experience repository had been made private, meaning that the artifacts were being uploaded somewhere inaccessible. Changing the repo to public, and re-uploading a new artifact, seemed to fix the problem. 

Fri, Feb 3rd - [Incident-8354 part 2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/digital-experience/buyer-experience/-/issues/1874): Same job in www starts failing, this time due to a 404 (file not found). After checking the difference between a recent successful "pages" deploy job in buyer experience, and comparing it to the most recent "pages" deploy job, we noticed that the runner was a private runner. We removed all private runners, and re-uploaded a new artifact. This seemed to fix the problem, and we assumed that the private runners were added to our repo when it had been made private yesterday. 

Fri, Feb 10th - Same as last week, the artifact starts 404-ing. The repo is public, there are no private runners. Looking at the last "pages" deploy in buyer experience, it was the automatic changelog job. I created a new MR, merged it in order to create a new artifact, and went over and re-ran the failed jobs in buyer experience, which seemed to fix the problem. 

#### Theories
Simply due to the fact that the changelog job had been run immediately prior to each of the 3 incidents, we may need to investigate how it may be affecting our CI. Especially since we're seeing these 404 failures on Friday's (the changelog script has [recently been changed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/digital-experience/buyer-experience/-/merge_requests/1642) to run every second Friday). My instinct is to let the job run on it's own in 2 weeks and see if we run into problems, or manually run the job and keep an eye on www pipelines. 

**If this is urgent, what is the business need for the urgency?**
- [x]  Yes: This blocks all MRs from building & deploying in the handbook, blog, and some marketing web pages. 
- [ ]  No

title: [ENG] Identify Enterprise user and display MVC variation in navigation
description:
## Goal

To utilize the [Demandbase API](https://support.demandbase.com/hc/en-us/sections/360011444531-API-Documentation) to identify if a visitor is coming from an Enterprise organization. They will be identified if:

- They have an existing Demandbase cookie set
- That cookie was mapped to a company
- If their IP address has been identified to obtain company identification

If the user is identified as Enterprise, we'll display a very MVC to the navigation. This subtle change in the navigation will be tiny - such as slightly different text on a single nav item. 

The goal of the issue is to simply prove that we can personalize the navigation based on visitor identification using Demandbase. If we can prove successful here, we'll ask our product designers to create two navigation variations for a larger iteration.



## Which page(s) are involved in this request?
* about.gitlab.com - buyer experience pages

## Include any Figma files
* There is no figma for this change - we only want a very small text change here

## In scope
What is within scope of this request?

- [ ] Identify 1 small text change in the navigation we can make for a enterprise user
- [ ] Build logic into navigation that enables us to show and hide the elements based on user type
- [ ] Ship this change to production

title: Create GDK cookie to recognize logged in user on marketing site
description:
## Goal

We would like to create a first party cookie in the product that will enable the marketing site to recognize a logged in Gitlab user.

### Engineering Notes

The user's session ID can be stored in a cookie on the client-side, and sent with each request to the server. The server can then look up the user's session in the database(or API) to determine if they are logged in or not.

This solution was also suggested by a Staff Support Engineer in the `#g_manage_auth` slack channel

#### How

1. **Assign a unique session ID to each user when they log in**: When a user logs in, generate a unique session ID for them and store it in a cookie on their device.
1. **Store the session ID in a shared database(or API):** Store the session ID in a database that can be accessed by both repositories. This allows us verify the user's login status by checking if their session ID is present in the database.
1. **Verify the user's login status with each request**: On each request from the user's device, both repositories can check the session ID in the cookie against the session ID stored in the database. If the session IDs match, the user is considered to be logged in.
1. **Update the cookie when the user logs out**: When the user logs out, you can delete their session ID from the database and remove the cookie from their device.

#### Problems

1. Potential scaling issues: performance issues may arise with a larger user base but this could be mitigated by sharding
1. Latency
1. Security? May need to flag that team for awareness and implementing some sort of encryption for the cookies
1. Maintenance? May need to onboard more people in GDK to maintain this
1. Cookies are client-side so the user maybe clear the cookies at any point. We should implement a fallback method like a session time-out that requires the user to log back in after \~12-24 hours

## Which page(s) are involved in this request?
* gitlab.org


## In scope
What is within scope of this request?

- [ ] Create the cookie for gitlab.com
